stream_context.summary: Kaze greyboxed/outlined Course 13’s ice-castle platforming by prototyping core traversal mechanics—especially a crack-and-break ice platform with a proper dissolve/break animation and supporting particle VFX. Along the way he iterated on a constrained N64 material setup (Fast64/SM64 rendering) and accidentally fixed a long-standing pointer misalignment bug that stopped music/animations in a later area.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces/locks in multiple Course 13 platforming mechanics, delivers a working crack→break platform prototype with VFX, and includes an accidental fix for a serious pointer/memory bug affecting music/animations.

findings.summary: Course 13’s immediate goal is to greybox the level by creating a set of reusable platforming pieces (3D models first) and then building the fun around them, rather than scripting encounters before the geometry exists.

Kaze lists candidate “signature” ice-castle mechanics to build: forward-moving ice waves you can slide on, crack-on-first-jump/break-on-second platforms, wind gusts (implying architectural features like windows), spinning ice shards with directional jump-offs, and large swinging axes; he prioritizes the crack platform, spinning shards, and wind gusts first.

He wants an appearing-path mechanic (inspired by Mario Galaxy-style paths that reveal as you approach) and considers placing it in one of the castle’s “abyss rooms,” but notes the castle was modeled without planning for it—so it must be integrated retroactively.

The “cracking ice platform” becomes an advanced N64 material problem: he needs cracks to intensify over time and then transition into a convincing disappearance/break, within heavy constraints (texture formats like I4/I8, 32x32 textures, limited channels where color/alpha share data).

He prototypes a two-texture approach where one texture provides base ice color/gradient and another provides crack detail, then uses primitive alpha/threshold-like logic to control crack visibility and a separate dissolve phase; Blender previews don’t match in-engine, requiring repeated in-game validation.

He implements and debugs the dissolve timing using blend-color/graphics state, initially failing due to reading the wrong timer source (accidentally reading a display list head pointer instead of the object timer) and later due to using the wrong display-list macro/function, causing broken rendering until corrected.

A new geo function created for the ice platform initially crashed because he forgot to return properly; fixing it led to an unexpected side effect: it may have also resolved a separate intermittent pointer misalignment bug where entering a second area caused music and animations to stop.
findings.quote: In this level I had a bug that sometimes all the ROM pointers would get misaligned—so when you enter the second area, the music and the animations would stop working.

findings.summary: He adds particle VFX to mask the harshness of the break: triangle shards (reusing breakable-box shatter logic but recolored) plus a mist/dust puff; he iterates on velocity randomness, fall direction, spawn flags, and color selection to better sell the break.

The intended gameplay rule for the crack platform: first contact begins cracking; after enough interaction it breaks so Mario can fall through; he also wants platforms to reset/respawn after time so the level can’t become unwinnable.

Kaze debates whether to reintroduce a movement quirk removed by a bug fix (a setup that enabled a triple-jump-like exploit). He’s undecided and asks chat, framing it as a choice between preserving fun tech vs preventing cheese; removing “kicks” is suggested as an alternative anti-cheese approach.
findings.quote: I’m 50-50 on whether I want it in the game, because it kind of feels like an exploit already.

findings.summary: He confirms Course 13’s “solar castle” section will use ice physics, indicating movement feel is a deliberate part of this course’s identity and not just visual theming.

Biobak actively drives implementation details: provides the appearing-path concept, shares Blender files/material setups for the ice effect, and gives visual direction (cracks should read as white), shaping both the mechanic and its readability.
Kaze says he has no dedicated video editor and that this limits outsourcing/editing because an editor would need technical context; he still plans to upload the full OST as a playlist later.
Kaze reveals a major near-term life change: he and Zeina are expecting a baby girl in about two months, which affects expectations for external commitments (he doubts he can do an “F3” this year).

biobak.summary: Proposed/advocated for the “appearing path” platforming idea (path reveals as you approach), which Kaze wants to include despite not having planned for it during initial castle modeling.
Provided a Blender reference file/material concept (e.g., iceeffect.blend) and suggested shader/material approaches for crack/dissolve behavior, which Kaze adapted into an in-engine solution.
Gave art-direction feedback that the cracks should read as white for better visual language, highlighting a readability problem in Kaze’s early blue/low-contrast versions.

zeina.summary: Zeina is referenced in personal context (pregnancy, baby name jokes) and as a supporter (both Kaze and Zeina subbed on stream); Kaze notes she likely doesn’t know the technical details of his rendering/material work, implying a division between art/animation and low-level engine tasks.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions Arthur wanted to fix the pointer misalignment bug (music/animations stopping), but Kaze may have fixed it incidentally while working on the new geo function—suggesting ongoing parallel debugging efforts within the broader collaborator circle.

A viewer reports Fast64/MatStackFix changes how lighting works, prompting Kaze to explain that with MatStackFix you must set prim and env (or prim/nth) colors in code instead of relying on light colors embedded in model data.

key_stories.title: Building the crack-and-break ice platform for Course 13
key_stories.summary: Kaze set out to create a signature ice platform that visually cracks and then breaks, but the real challenge was making it read well and animate convincingly within N64 rendering limits. He iterated through multiple material strategies, debugged mismatches between Blender and in-engine output, and ultimately added particle VFX to hide the harshness of the final transition.
key_stories.challenge: Designing an ice platform that (1) shows progressive cracking, (2) cleanly transitions to a break/disappear state, and (3) remains readable, all under N64 texture/material constraints.
key_stories.process: Prioritized this mechanic for the course; experimented with two-texture setups and primitive alpha/threshold control; tested repeatedly in-game; adjusted timing curves to avoid sudden vanishing; added triangle shard particles and a mist puff; discussed respawn/reset behavior so the level can’t softlock.
key_stories.outcome: A workable prototype exists (crack phase + break visuals + VFX), but Kaze is still unsatisfied with readability/quality and expects further iteration or inspiration later.

key_stories.title: Accidentally fixing a major pointer misalignment bug while adding a geo function
key_stories.summary: While implementing a new geo/material function for the ice platform, Kaze hit crashes due to a missing return and other mistakes. After correcting them, he realized the changes may have also fixed an unrelated long-standing issue where pointers misaligned and later-area music/animations stopped.
key_stories.challenge: A recurring, hard-to-reproduce bug caused ROM/RAM pointer misalignment that broke music and animations when entering a later area.
key_stories.process: Kaze implemented and debugged a new geo function (fixing a crash and a copied bug), then noticed the previous issue no longer reproduced and inferred the change may have resolved it.
key_stories.outcome: Bug possibly fixed “by accident,” reinforcing Kaze’s tendency to defer some bug fixing until late because fixes can emerge from adjacent work.
key_stories.key_quote: No way that fixed the bug—what the fuck.

key_stories.title: Deciding whether to preserve unintended movement tech
key_stories.summary: A bug fix removed a trick that allowed a triple-jump-like setup. Kaze treats it as a design decision rather than a purely technical one, weighing whether it’s fun emergent tech or a cheese/exploit that undermines intended challenge.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing player expression/tech with level integrity and preventing sequence breaks.
key_stories.process: Kaze explains the change, tests movement, asks chat for opinions, and considers alternative restrictions (e.g., removing kicks) instead of restoring the exact exploit.
key_stories.outcome: Decision deferred; flagged as a design call to revisit.
